dull.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Life is never dull when Elizabeth is here.
It sounded pretty dull to me.
The weekly meeting tends to be deadly dull (=very dull).
Last week we had a hurricane. Never a dull moment running a hotel in the Caribbean  (=it’s always interesting or exciting).
dull.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say boring rather than dull:
dull.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The bird is dull brown and gray in colour.
Her eyes were dull with dark shadows beneath them.
dull.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: not bright and with lots of clouds
dull.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Outside the weather was hazy and dull.
dull.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a dull pain is not severe but does not stop
dull.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: a dull ache in her lower back
The pain was dull but persistent.
dull.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The gates shut with a dull thud.
dull.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: not able to think quickly or understand things easily
dull.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: If you don’t understand then you’re duller than I thought.
dull.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if business on the Stock Exchange is dull, few people are buying and selling
dull.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to make something become less sharp or clear
dull.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He drank some alcohol to dull the pain.
Her fear and anxiety dulled her mind.
dull.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to become less bright or loud, or to make something become less bright or loud
dull.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The constant rain dulled all sound.
dull.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if business on a financial market is dull, not many people are buying or selling
dull.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Shares closed lower in dull trading.
Investors were busy moving in and out of two-year Treasury notes yesterday, providing a bit of excitement to an otherwise dull session.
